msgSnippet: Damn, J.B. -- two great posts from you today.  I take it you ve been in this business for a while? Scott Stirling JRun QA Macromedia ...

Subject: RE: [junit] RE: Why doesn't JUnit count asserts
Date: Wed, 18 Jul 2001 16:38:31 -0400
MIME-Version: 1.0
X-Mailer: Internet Mail Service (5.5.2650.21)
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="iso-8859-1"
From: Scott Stirling <sstirling@...>

Damn, J.B. -- two great posts from you today.  I take it you've been in this
business for a while?

Scott Stirling
JRun QA
Macromedia

> -----Original Message-----
> From: rainsber@... [mailto:rainsber@...]
> Sent: Wednesday, July 18, 2001 3:29 PM
> To: junit@yahoogroups.com
> Subject: RE: [junit] RE: Why doesn't JUnit count asserts
> 
> 
> Understood, and thanks for bringing us back to the point of 
> the thread. My
> final words on the subject: if management cares about how 
> many assertions
> there are, then before long, so will the developers. If you 
> don't want them
> to care, then you should consider finding a way for 
> management to get the
> information they want without counting assertions.
> 
> An interesting discussion. Thanks.
> 
> J. B. Rainsberger  <rainsber@...>
> Commerce Suite Accelerator: Rule Services, IBM Toronto Lab
> 8200 Warden Av, Office A3-735 [A3/FNB/8200/MKM]
> Markham ON   L6G 1C7
> 905 413-2501 (969-2501)
> 
> 
> "Jason Rogers" <jason.rogers@...> on 07/18/2001 15:18:10
> 
> Please respond to junit@yahoogroups.com
> 
> To:   "'junit@yahoogroups.com'" <junit@yahoogroups.com>
> cc:
> Subject:  RE: [junit] RE: Why doesn't JUnit count asserts
> 
> 
> 
> Since I started this whole debate off...
> 
> I want to make very clear that the only reason we counted 
> asserts was for
> the mgmt. team's sake.  The developers could care less.  Also, the
> developers didn't care exactly how many tests were written.  
> What we wanted
> to know was that we had tested everything that could possibly 
> break.  End
> of
> story for us.
> 
> -Jason
> 
>
